-e ---
---
Egyptians loved confusing subtleties and puns.  

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/516118/36503030-10d18802-174c-11e8-96db-219ebc69ab35.png)  

Some of the subtleties are purely the result of our ignorance, others are intended:  


Subtleties can serve in representing two words with very similar meanings but different (sometimes similar) phonetics.

# Postulated dialectic forms:

ğ“†™ â‹ ğ“†‘ â‰  [ğ“†‘](ğ“†‘.html) snake schnecke  
[ğ“‡‹ğ“‡‹](ğ“‡‹ğ“‡‹.html) [ğ“‡Œ](ğ“‡Œ.html) [ğ“‡‹](ğ“‡‹.html) ğ“‡‹ ğ“†„ğ“†„  

auf ğ“‚ & ab ğ“‚£  [arm](arm.html)  
up ğ“‚ & down ğ“‚£ & ğ“‚¢  

Organic series of sign simplification / rotation / ligatures  
ğ“¹ ğ“º ğ“» ğ“¼ ğ“½ ğ“¿ ğ“‚€  
ğ“„¹ ğ“„¼ ğ“„º ğ“„»  
 ğ“‡¢ ğ“‡  ğ“‡¡  

Much of the gardiner A,B,C series (man, women, gods) naturally seems subtly related:  
[ğ“€—](ğ“€—.html) [ğ“€˜](ğ“€˜.html) [ğ“€™](ğ“€™.html) [ğ“€š](ğ“€š.html) [ğ“€›](ğ“€›.html)  

Often these signs carry micro [ligatures](ligatures.html) :  
ğ“†µ ğ“†¶ ğ“†´ ğ“‚‹ ğ“Šª ğ“ presumably pointing to diverged but related (dialectic) forms and meanings.  
ğ“‡ˆ ğ“‡Š ğ“‡‡ ğ“‡‰  
[ğ“‚](ğ“‚.html) [ğ“‚ ](ğ“‚ .html) [ğ“‚Ÿ](ğ“‚Ÿ.html) [ğ“‚¦](ğ“‚¦.html) [ğ“‚¥](ğ“‚¥.html) [ğ“‚¡](ğ“‚¡.html) [ğ“‚¢](ğ“‚¢.html)  
[ğ“Œº](ğ“Œº.html) [ğ“Œ¹](ğ“Œ¹.html) [ğ“Œ¸](ğ“Œ¸.html) [ğ“Œ»](ğ“Œ».html) [ğ“Œ¼](ğ“Œ¼.html) [ğ“](ğ“.html)

[ğ“¶](ğ“¶.html) [ğ“‡¬](ğ“‡¬.html)

[ğ“Š](ğ“Š.html) [ğ“](ğ“.html) [ğ“Œ‡](ğ“Œ‡) [ğ“Œˆ](ğ“Œˆ) [ğ“Œ‰](ğ“Œ‰.html)  
ğ“Œ ğ“ŒŸ ğ“Œ   
[ğ“Œš](ğ“Œš.html) [ğ“Œ™](ğ“Œ™.html) [ğ“Œ˜](ğ“Œ˜.html) [ğ“Ÿ](ğ“Ÿ.html)

[ğ“¢](ğ“¢.html) [ğ“²](ğ“².html) [ğ“¬](ğ“¬.html)  
As in sumerian many similar signs developed through natural evolution and simplification  
[ğ“„Ÿ](ğ“„Ÿ.html)	[ğ“„ ](ğ“„ .html)  
[ğ’‚¡](ğ’‚¡.html) [ğ’‚¦](ğ’‚¦.html) â‡” [ğ’†Ÿ](ğ’†Ÿ.html)  á¸«ir < Å¡irâ‚ƒ < girâ‚â‚ â‰  ğ’”  
[ğ’„­](ğ’„­.html) ğ’„­ ğ’Š® ğ’² ğ’†  á¸ªIÂ®  Å ARâ‚‚ SAÂ® Å Ã€Â® KIÂ® [KUR](KUR.html)  

Ligature series may look like subtleties but are straightforward:  
ğ’Œ« ğ’Œ³ ğ’Œ¬ ğ’Œ­ ğ’Œ® ğ’Œ¯ ğ’Œ° ğ’Œ± ğ’Œ²  
ğ’„­ ğ’Š® ğ’² ğ’†  ğ’„² ğ’„³ ğ’„´ ğ’„µ ğ’„¶ â€¦  
ğ’” => ğ’’­  ğ’”‚ ğ’”ƒ ğ’”„ ğ’”… ğ’”† ğ’”‡ ğ’”ˆ ğ’”‰ ğ’”Š ğ’”‹  

Others come from different time periods, languages and scribal traditions:  
ğ’ˆ â‰  [ğ](ğ.html)  
ğ’ˆ« â‰  [ğ•](ğ•.html)  
ğ’‰º â‹ [ğ€](ğ€.html)  
[ğ’](ğ’.html) BÃ€D â‹ [ğ“„‹](ğ“„‹.html) [PART](PART.html) but â‹ Bote  
[ğ€](ğ€.html) â‰  ğ’€ DIDLI  
[ğ’„Š](ğ’„Š.html) < [ğ’€²](ğ’€².html)[ğ’†³](ğ’†³.html)[ğ’Š](ğ’Š.html) kur+ra ğ“ƒ— à¤˜à¥‹à¤¡à¤¼à¤¾ ghoá¹›Ä  [ğ’„Š](ğ’„Š.html) GÃŒR Gir ğ“… Geier [ğ“‚»](ğ“‚».html) â‡” [ğ“‚¾](ğ“‚¾.html)[ğ“ƒ€](ğ“ƒ€.html)  
[ğ’‚‰](ğ’‚‰.html) DUR â‡” á´°ray æ—¥ rÃ¬ ğ“‡³ ri â€¢duri ğ“‡³ [dura](dura.html) ğ“‡¶ dry [3](3.html)  
[ğ’—](ğ’—.html) â‹ [ğ“±](ğ“±.html) mÅ«tu muert â€œdeathâ€  
[ğ’„­](ğ’„­.html) á¸ªI â€¢HEL â‰  [ğ’†¸](ğ’†¸.html) [Kuhle](Kuhle.html) [å£](å£.html) [KUR](KUR.html)

Yet others are harder to explain  
[ğ’‹°](ğ’‹°.html) [ğ”](ğ”.html) DU/BI [2](2.html) TAB double  
[ğ’†ª](ğ’†ª.html) [ğ’‚‰](ğ’‚‰.html) KUR DUR âš ï¸

ğ’ â‹ ğ’— ÃšÅ  â‹ ğ’Œ€ â‹ ğ’…‚ (Alternative forms) â‰  ğ’‘˜ EÅ E3 ğ’‘™ EÅ EMINâ‚… ğ’‡

Many look similar in Akkadian but not in their sumerian base form, which can yield insights:  
If it looks similar it likely sounds [similar](sound-changes).  

Some look similar by accident:  
[ğ“„¤](ğ“„¤.html) [ğ“„¥](ğ“„¥.html)  
[ğ’„‘](ğ’„‘.html) â‰  [ğ’€¶](ğ’€¶.html)  
[ğ’‹«](ğ’‹«.html) TA â‰  [ğ’€´](ğ’€´.html) ÃŒR  
[ğ’‡·](ğ’‡·.html) [ğ’Œ…](ğ’Œ….html) LIË¢ â‰  TU  
[ğ’‹†](ğ’‹†.html) â‰  [ğ’‰](ğ’‰.html) [ğ’‹«](ğ’‹«.html) gunu  
[ğ’†¦](ğ’†¦.html) gunÃ» â‰  [ğ’ƒ²](ğ’ƒ².html) gal  
[ğ’€–](ğ’€–.html) AP â‰  ğ’†• DU [ğ“š](ğ“š.html) DIU ğ“™ duo Delta  â‰   

Many are components of each other (reverse ligatures)  
[ğ’„±](ğ’„±.html) AR2 â‰  [ğ’‹¼](ğ’‹¼.html) TE/TEÄœ3/TEN  

Interestingly the more complicated original form often has a more simple phonetic value and may even be used as alphabetic/syllabic sign dispite its higher complexity, presumably to alleviate ambiguity.  
E.g. ğ“  vs ğ“ˆ™ in Darius inscriptions.  

Often these carry similar sounds / meanings, despite their temporal distance.  


# Ablauts, Umlauts
It is possible that some of the ligatures represented Ablauts: change of vowels to change cases or semantics:  

[ğ“ˆ˜](ğ“ˆ˜.html) [ğ“ˆ](ğ“ˆ.html) rod road à¤°à¥‹à¤¡ roá¸ river á½Î´ÏŒÏ‚ hodÃ³s (corruption when?)  

[Ï€](Ï€.html)-forms versus [Âµ](Âµ.html)-forms  

Baum ğ“® => BÃ¤ume [ğ’€](ğ’€.html) [TÃ¼ttel](TÃ¼ttel.html)
